Award.AwardTitle: AitF: Spectral Methods in the Field: New Tools for Discovering Latent Structure in Societal-Scale Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The rapid rise in the use of mobile phones, social media, and digital sensors has created opportunities to observe and understand the rapidly changing structure of populations around the world. In particular, the data captured on these population-scale digital networks can inform policy-relevant questions about the evolving nature of societies around the world. For example, policymakers would like to know how idiosyncratic violence impacts the resilience of local communities, how the presence of foreign troops changes local patterns of interaction, and how draughts and natural disasters affect feelings of national solidarity. Unfortunately, appropriate models and algorithms do not exist to make sense of evolving, societal-scale data. This project will develop scalable algorithms to help make sense of real-world networked sensor data, with the potential for significant impact in the increasingly connected global society.

The technical focus of this project is on adapting recent algorithmic advances in the theoretical computer science and machine learning literatures to real-world, societal-scale network data. This approach will leverage recent advances in spectral methods, which provide provably efficient algorithms for estimating hidden structure in data and improve upon the state of the art in three important ways. The first objective is to adapt and scale current spectral models to real-world datasets with millions of interconnected actors, which have weighted and directed edges with heavy-tailed degree distributions. The second goal is to translate existing methods to dynamic regime, to address the non-stationary nature of real-world data. The third goal is to characterize the computational and statistical limits of what can be achieved with these models. The algorithms and tools developed through this research will be made available to the broader academic community via open source code repositories such as GitHub and BitBucket.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal's goals were to adapt recent algorithmic advances in theoretical computer science and machine learning to build methods for discovering latent variable models and for scalable estimation, capable of reliably discovering hidden structure in societal-scale network data. Through this project, we developed provably efficient, accurate and scalable algorithms for estimating hidden structure in dynamic data; we also applied these methods in empirical settings to draw social and economic inferences from continuously evolving, population-scale, social network datasets.

In the final year of the project, we had the opportunity to adapt and apply our work on this project to several COVID-related efforts. The first was focused on public health management, and consisted of work to improve contact tracing (both manual and digital) and the methods for estimating COVID prevalence and resource requirements. The second used societal scale digital data from developing countries to help direct emergency humanitarian aid. Each of these efforts were huge interdisciplinary collaborations between theoretical computer scientists, mobile networking experts, social scientists, epidemiologists, and medical doctors. 

Intellectual Merit:

Our project made both theoretical and empirical contributions.  Regarding theory, our project developed novel techniques to recover populations of model parameters. Here the setting is that one has data provided by a large number of heterogeneous data sources, with each source providing relatively little data. (Such a setting arises in numerous places across the medical, biological, and information sciences.) The question is the extent to which the large number of sources can compensate for the lack of data from each source. We established both information theoretic limits along with practical algorithms. We also provided more accurate procedures for how to correct for the measurement bias when inferring changes in sparse, societal-scale data, including meaningful metrics like network degree or network entropy. Our most recent work here has opened new lines of research on sublinear (and optimal) estimation in settings where there are covariates (this line of work draws new connections to the recent meta-learning framework in machine learning).

We have applied these methods in several social science settings, revealing novel insights that would not be possible with traditional data or methods. One line of work used these scalable methods to measure the impact of violence and conflict on the structure of social networks. More recent work has applied these algorithms to the study of human mobility during COVID. We have also developed new approaches to using large social network data to measure population demographics, which is now being used to improve the targeting of humanitarian aid.

Broader impact:

Our work on the COVID19 pandemic had immediate consequences and influenced policy makers both in the US and abroad. Domestically, we have provided guidance for when lockdowns should occur, and also developed guidelines for the number of tests and contact tracers required for controlling outbreaks. Our multidisciplinary efforts also helped develop new contact tracing methodologies, along with a prototype. This laid the foundations for the new Exposure Notification App now deployed in WA state. 

Internationally, we have been working directly with the governments of several developing countries to improve COVID response by deriving time-sensitive insights from large-scale digital data. In Togo, for instance, we have helped design a new system for targeting and distributing emergency humanitarian aid, which uses data from satellites and mobile phone networks to identify individuals and families with the greatest need for support. These methods have the potential to transform the way that the international development community approaches rapid emergency response.
